awd_titl_txt: CRII: CSR: Federated Resource Management in Mobile Edge Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart cities are urban areas that use Internet connected devices, called the Internet-of-Things (IoT), to collect and analyze large amounts of data to increase the productivity and efficiency of city resources. Smart home sensors and smartphones are examples of things used in the era of smart cities, each creating a tremendous amount of data that needs to be processed. Edge computing is an emerging technology used to process such large amounts of data in real-time. Edge computing also poses new resource management challenges due to its limited capacity. This project focuses on optimization of resource management in edge and cloud computing frameworks.

This project proposes to use concepts of federated learning and reinforcement learning to provide optimal solutions for service placement and request scheduling in multi-tier edge and cloud computing frameworks. This project will focus on new algorithms and system design technologies to trade off the quality-of-service (QoS) and the cost in edge computing systems. Three main thrusts include: 1) finding theoretical bounds through mathematical formulation and algorithm design, 2) finding more practical and adaptive solutions through multi-agent reinforcement learning and the federated learning framework, and 3) comparison of practical solutions with theoretical bounds through numerical analysis and implementations on a mobile edge computing test-bed. 

This project will have impacts on the future IoT and smart cities applications by improving the cost of providing such applications while maintaining certain QoS levels for users. Algorithms and an optimization framework developed in this project will contribute to the research in design and development of scalable and reliable edge computing systems as building blocks of IoT applications. This research will be integrated into classroom teaching as a special topics graduate level course offered by the investigator. Specific outreach activities for middle school, high school and Berea College students aim to increase participation of underrepresented groups in computer science.

The data produced by this project including codes, experimental results, videos of talks, and publications will be shared using the project page that will be maintained during the lifetime of this project. Upon finalizing the two-year term of the project, an archive of the project webpage and information will be digitally stored and made available upon request by any researcher or entity if the webpage is taken down. Link to the project repository: http://www.cs.uky.edu/~khamfroush/fed-mec.php.  This project is jointly funded by the Computer Systems Research Program in the Division of Computer and Network Systems and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mobile edge computing (MEC) represents a transformative technology that brings computational resources closer to users, enabling faster and more efficient processing of data in applications ranging from autonomous vehicles to smart healthcare. This project focused on developing novel approaches for resource management in MEC systems, tackling challenges in optimizing computational resources, ensuring data privacy, and enhancing overall system performance.

Project Outcomes

This project advanced knowledge in resource management optimization for resource constrained environment such as edge computing. We developed novel solutions leveraging technologies such as federated machine learning and data compression that are shown to improve overall cost-performance tradeoff while improving the percentage of satisfied users by a factor of at least 50%. Our proposed federated learning based resource management solutions also provide better privacy/security for the entire system as decisions are made distributedly and no data related to users are shared.

Key technical outcomes include

1. novel distributed and federated resource allocation framework and improved overall performance. We designed distributed and federated algorithms that learn from previous user demands and dynamically allocate computational and communication resources across edge devices. These frameworks consider network conditions, and application-specific quality of service (QoS) requirements, resulting in significant improvements in system efficiency.

2. novel data compression strategies for improved quality of service. We developed an optimized decision system that can automatically decide on the level of data compression and data offloading (where to serve user’s requests) to achieve a certain quality of service for users. Our proposed solutions achieve better overall accuracy-latency tradeoff, namely, 58% traffic reduction, 25% latency reduction, as well as 12% accuracy improvement.

 

The broader impacts of this work extend to society, education, and technology:

  1. Privacy-Preserving Applications:
    •  The project’s outcomes are particularly relevant for privacy-sensitive applications such as telemedicine and smart surveillance. By keeping sensitive data on local devices, the developed techniques mitigate privacy risks while still enabling the benefits of AI-driven insights.
  2. Energy Efficiency in Edge Networks:
    • By optimizing resource allocation, our methods reduce the energy consumption of MEC systems, contributing to sustainable computing practices and supporting the global push for greener technologies.
  3. Education and Workforce Development:
    • This project provided training opportunities for two graduate students and several undergraduate students in cutting-edge areas of federated learning, AI and edge computing, enhancing the technical capacity of the next generation of engineers and scientists. The research performed in this project contributed to two phd dissertation. 
  4. Economic and Technological Advancements:
    • Federated resource management has significant implications for industries reliant on real-time data processing, including telecommunications, transportation, and manufacturing. The techniques developed here pave the way for more robust and efficient systems that can support innovative services and applications.

Over the duration of this award, we published 8 papers, have one paper under-review, graduated two phd students who were working on the project for some part of their phd, mentored several undergrad students.
